items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob Nuñez, SuperintendentSUBJECT:Academic Master Plan Standardization; Cost Estimate for Standardization; Process for Integration of Measure E Bond Projects with Academic Master PlanThe Board of Trustees of the EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT identified a goal of developingand implementing an Academic Master Plan (AMP) that would close the achievement gap while improving the overall academic performance of all students. The Academic Master Plan initiative was designed to guide District policy and practice through the year 2015 by integrating programs, services, and facilities for 21st century student success.The three major areas of focus for the AMP included:Identification of specific programs and projects that would meet the needs of the 21st century studentIdentification of practices and programs to narrow the achievement gap and meet the requirement of Program ImprovementRecommendations on the utilization of Measure E fundsThe plan included the identification of an intersection between academic programs and renovated and newly constructed facilities, technology and equipment that provides the district with an innovative approach to equitably prioritizing resources.Approximately 450 projects were identified based on the following documents:Academic Master Plan School Site Council Project Priority ListStandardization Recommendations for Measure E fundingTechnology Master PlanDeferred Maintenance PlanFacilities Master Plan by Perkins & Will The projects identified were from the twelve main campuses and sixteen alternative campuses, charters, and programs. The cost of each project and program was individually estimated. It was determined that the total cost for all direct and indirect project costs is approximately one billion dollars. The following process was used to select the projects to be funded from the $349,000,000 allocated in Measure E:Specific criteria were developed by a team of stakeholders, including the Superintendent, Cabinet members, the Director of Technology, the Director of Construction and Facilities, the Assistant Director of Maintenance and representatives of SGI.  Each project was ranked using criteria grouped into four categories:21st Century Achievement GoalsHigh Priority EfficiencyEquityTwo major district-wide criteria were developed to provide a weighted campus ranking:Academic Performance – greatest share to go to the lowest performers based on a ration of test scores.Share of funds from previous bonds – greatest share to go to campuses that previously received the least, in proportion to amounts received.The final allocation of funds and selection of projects is based on a combination of project ranking criteria, previous bond allocations and the District goal of closing the achievement gap. The Academic Master Plan proved to be a comprehensive, equitable and transparent project which will enable EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT to continue to produce students who will be productive citizens of the 21st Century.RECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Governing Board adopt the Academic Master Plan which contains recommendations for the allocation of Measure E funds.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business ServicesSUBJECT:Approve Proposed Ground Lease Agreement for New City Library at Indpendence High SchoolSince 1976 the City of San Jose has operated a 14,000 square foot branch public library on District property located adjacent to the Independence High School site.  The Lease between the City and ESUHSD is for a term of 50 years plus one option to renew the lease for an additional 49 years; there is potentially approximately 67 years of term remaining on the existing lease.  Rent under the existing lease is $1.00 per year.  Pursuant to the existing lease, the City and library patrons also have the right to use a parking area for the library at the Independence site.  Also, the existing lease requires the District to provide for nearly all maintenance to the library building at the District’s sole cost and expense.The City now desires to construct at City’s own cost a new 18,000 square foot branch library building on approximately 1.6 acres of land on District property in a new location just south of the existing library building and adjacent to the Overfelt Gardens Park.  The proposed term for the new ground lease is 40 years plus one option to extend for 5 additional years.  Under the proposed agreement the City would construct and maintain its own branch library building at its own cost and expense and utilities would be separately metered to the new building so that all such charges will be billed directly to, and paid directly by, the City; the City would also construct and maintain its own parking facility for the new library.  Once construction of the new library commences, the lease for the existing library building will terminate 90 days thereafter and possession of the existing library building will revert to the District for its own use and purposes.   FISCAL IMPACT:N/AFUNDING SOURCE:N/ARECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the attach Ground Lease Agreement with the City of San Jose for the new Library at Independence High School.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Dan Moser, Associate Superintendent of Instruction and Human RelationsSUBJECT:Approve 2009 Summer School ProgramOur thirty-day summer school program which begins June 18, 2009 and ends July 30, 2009 (no school on Friday, July 3rd), will be available again for students in grades 9-12.  Supported by the State of California, the State reimbursed classes include: classes for 9th  grade students at risk of failing the High School Exit Exam (CAHSEE), classes for 10th through 12th grade students who have failed subjects needed to pass the CAHSEE and for certain students in Special Education.  The State reimbursed classes are listed below:	English 1 (make-up)		English 2 (make-up)				Algebra I (make-up)		Geometry (make-up)	Incoming Freshmen Summer Program	Reading					English Language Development (ELD)	High School Exit Exam PreparationThe estimated reimbursement from the State will continue to be on an hourly basis at the rate of $4.08 per student hour of attendance minus any applied deficit factor.Additionally, the Governor’s budget allows for enrichment and make-up classes in academic core areas other than those listed above at all grade levels.  The number of classes that can be offered is capped based on the District’s 2007 CBED’s enrollment.  Based on the state formula, the District can offer these classes to approximately 1,250 students.  This funding will be used to offer courses in the identified core academic areas as well as some elective areas consistent with the District’s Graduation Requirements.  These sections will also be funded at $3.60 per student hour of attendance minus any applied deficit factor.  Any classes beyond the cap allowed by the state are an encroachment offset by other funding from summer school. The courses offered will be from the following academic core areas:	English/Language Arts			Mathematics	Science					Social Science			Foreign Language				Fine Arts	Physical EducationA description of some of the summer school programs are described below:1.	Classes for students not demonstrating sufficient progress towards passing the CAHSEEPrograms in this category include: the Summer Language Arts and Math Institute; CAHSEE Intervention Courses; Repeat Algebra I; Repeat Geometry; English Language Development Courses; Valdes Summer Math Institute and others as appropriate. 2.	Make-up Classes Make-up classes will be offered to non-graduating 2009 seniors needing to make-up required courses for graduation.Next priority will be given to 11th and 12th grade students and those students not demonstrating sufficient progress towards passing the CAHSEE.  Students in the 9th and 10th grades who need make-up classes will be accommodated if space permits. 3.	EnrichmentEach school will receive student slots equaling 3% of their CBED’s enrollment, as of October 2007.  We project 700 students will be able to take advantage of enrichment courses.  These classes can be used for magnet, academy and other special programs for students who need to take extra elective classes during the school year required by those programs.  Any student wishing to advance in a curricular area or to take an elective can also enroll in a summer enrichment course.  Enrichment courses are limited to the following academic areas:  English/Language Arts, Science, Foreign Language, Mathematics, Social Science, Fine Arts or Physical Education.  Principals will make the decision about which enrichment courses are offered for which students.  The site MUST get the district’s approval for each section offered.4.	Language Arts and Math Summer Institute (SMLI)The goals of the SMLI are to prepare students who are not demonstrating sufficient progress towards passing the CAHSEE for success in Algebra 1 and English 1, articulate with feeder school teachers about student achievement and curriculum focused on CAHSEE standards, and to provide professional development on best practices relating to teaching strategies and curriculum designed to prepare students for rigor of high school.5.	Special EducationSpecial Education classes will be offered on all Summer School sites for Special Day Class (SDC) students who qualify for Extended School Year (ESY) services per their IEP.  RSP students may attend the regular summer school classes if needed for graduation credit.  Funding for the SDC students is provided through a daily allocation from the State Department.6.	ELL Summer SchoolThe goal is to increase the English skills of our ELL students in listening, speaking, reading and writing to a level high enough to pass the CELDT assessment at the proficient and advanced levels.  The extra support that summer school can provide will also help these students become more successful in the core curriculum classes preventing them from falling behind in meeting the graduation requirements.  This summer school program is part of the CAHSEE preparation program that is a reimbursement program from the State Department.7. 	Migrant EducationMigrant Education will be offering a summer bridge program for incoming 9th graders that been identified as migrant education students as part of the Summer Math Language Institute.  Only continuing district migrant education students will have the opportunity to recover credits through the Portable Assisted Study Sequence (PASS) Program in the areas of Mathematics, English, Social Science, and Science.  They can also earn elective credits by taking courses such as Study Skills, Career Exploration, Economic Decision Making, etc.  Incoming 12th grade migrant education students will attend a one-week college experience program that will be held on a local college campus.8.	Valdes Summer Math InstituteThe Valdes Summer Math Institute will be made available to students from our feeder schools currently in 6th, and 7th grades not demonstrating sufficient progress towards passing the California High School Exit Exam (CAHSEE).  The operation of this project has been a cooperative effort between the ESUHSD and our feeder school districts.  The goals of the program are to increase the number of students in Calculus for under-represented groups by preparing them for success in Algebra 1 upon entering high school, reduce the risk of students dropping out of school, and pass the CAHSEE as sophomores.  It is anticipated that the project will be housed at various local colleges and universities.  The enrollment will consist of approximately 500- 800 students. ESUHSD and its feeder elementary districts will have agreements allowing feeder district summer school ADA to fund classes for Algebra 1 and below.  The Institute will use enrichment ADA to fund higher-level classes if available.  9.	California High School Exit Exam (CAHSEE) InterventionSummer school sites will offer California High School Exit Exam (CAHSEE) Intervention classes for students who have taken and failed the CAHSEE to prepare students for future CAHSEE testing. CAHSEE testing will take place at all summer school sites on the July 28 and 29, 2009.10. items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Alan Garofalo, Associate Superintendent of Student Services and FacilitiesRichard Uribe, Director of Adult EducationSUBJECT:Approve Carl D. Perkins 132 Grant 2008-09 Grant Application for East Side Adult Education ProgramOverview:The East Side Adult Education Program is part of a five program Career Technical Education consortium to receive Carl Perkins funding.  Under its guidelines adult education agencies who can not generate $50,000 in grant funding may apply for funding under a consortium model.  The four partners in the consortium are Metropolitan Adult Education, Mountain View-Los Altos Adult Education, Santa Clara Adult Education, and Sunnyvale-Cupertino Adult Education.  With the assistance of our consortium members, the East Side Adult Education has served as the lead partner in this consortium and is charged with submitting the application, monitoring the progress toward goal achievement, and evaluating the Carl Perkins plan annually.Accomplishments:Utilizing information for Central Santa Clara County from the Employment Development Department, input from the five Adult Education Program Advisory Committees, and staff and student surveys, the CTE Consortium Advisory Committee identified two industry sectors and related career pathways addressed in this five year plan.  Perkins funds will be used to assist programs in Health and Science which will focus on Clinical Nursing, Medical Assistant, and Home Health Aide Assistant career pathways.  The second industry sector is Information Technology, which will focus on Administrative Assistant, Database Administrator, Support & Services Technician, Desktop Publishing, and Accounting career pathways.  The adult education programs in the consortium offer a thriving program for the completion of a secondary education and English language development and providing career learning opportunities in health, medicine, and information technology that have numerous entry and advancements options will complement our programs. FISCAL IMPACT:NoneFUNDING SOURCE:Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Improvement Act of 2006, Section 132RECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Carl D.
